chunks.original_text: 虽服世间小乘医，诸见诸疑莫能了。 愿请大慈大哀尊，为我为缘横演说。 我今无主国无君，四土众生皆饥馑。 我等四众亦如是，天尊付嘱反神身。 善寂常住不生死，我等孤露犹哀子。 失法失尊如枯凅，我等啼哭定当死。 唯愿不舍大慈心，普演一乘智藏城。 尔时，海空得闻偈已，即起白言：大哀天尊，譬喻言辞，犹如国王生育诸子，形貌端正，心弘爱念，教道经典，悉令通达，然后大王分付别国，统乘教化。 我今亦尔，犹如王子，蒙大哀天尊教诲具足，当还反神。 我等稽首大哀天尊，唯愿莫舍二道众生。 若大哀天尊久住於世，说甘露藏，充满一切。 如是众生不生畏想，堕於地狱。 譬如有人初作术学，为官所收，禁於狱中，徒伴问言：汝受何事，来入此狱？ 此人答言：我大忧恼，若其得脱，计当安乐，得大法力。 大哀天尊，亦复如是。 为诸众生，住於苦城，示未免苦，随众生意，权应现身。 大哀天尊教示善种，犹如药师，善解药分，复以妙药教授其子。 诸余外学受业之人，悉不得见。 今我天尊亦复如是，独以甚深微妙宝藏教授善种。 我今云何不见顾愍？ 平等妙法，应无秘吝。 如彼药师，独授其子，不授外学。 当知大师情有胜负，法宝秘惜，大慈之心终无胜负。 何以故？ 我今四众不见教诲，唯愿久住，为我演说。 譬如众生身有病苦，舍远夷涂而行崄道，崄道多难，构受众苦。 勿有异人见愍念之，即便教以平坦之路。 我等四众，亦复如是。 大哀天尊为大慈故，指示於我一乘宝藏。 以是之故，得晓空有平等之相。 尔时，天尊告海空言：汝等勿作如凡夫心，说有胜负。 汝等当以各共止愁，勿复忧恼。 当勤精进，存心正念。 若有所疑，恣汝问决。 我空不空，我常不常，我苦不苦，我依不依，我住不住，我去不去，我归不归； 忽有忽无，非常非非常，非乐非非乐，非断非非断，非真非非真，非灭非非灭； 如是种种，法中无量，随汝所问，随汝所疑。 我当随汝分别说之，亦当为汝说平等味。 吾过去后应世甚难，智慧身难，信汝身难，如是难者，难见难闻。 汝等久已成就大戒，具足功德，行无缺故，得见我身，希有希有，难可思议。 善男子，海空智藏，汝已久离生死八难，得金刚身，是故遇我，不应空过。 善男子，我於往昔过去劫时，种种勤苦，今得如是无上道果，方便之号，为汝等故，权应舍身，当还反神无为一乘海空法城，具足种种功德珍宝，随汝所取。 是故汝能庄严正法，解了空义。 汝能一心，种种积聚，包含若海，具足功德智慧心藏。 以是之故，汝今名为一乘海空智藏之号。 善男子，譬如商贾，遇得宝城，身自采取，而得还家，成大富贵。 汝亦如是，值遇我身，而得一乘，深了法藏，成就法身，亦复如是。 尔时，天尊告诸地仙：勿以下心而生足想。 汝今学者，虽得出家於此大乘，不生贪慕诸地仙等。 汝今四众身虽得服大慈悲衣，黄褐玄巾，心犹未染一乘法藏。 四众地仙虽行柔弱，经履名山，心未曾求大乘法藏，虽得出家，未为正法； 虽服五英，诸结未除。 我今大慈为海空藏，演说一乘真实教勑，汝等四众，我今现在，於大众中，和合要 决一乘法性，真实不倒。 以是之故，汝等四众应当摄心，勇猛精进，摧诸结恼，得法明净。
chunks.translated_text:
Though we have taken the lesser physicians of the worldly Small Vehicle,
None of their views, none of their doubts, could ever be resolved.
We beseech the Great Compassionate and Great Merciful Worthy,
For our sake and for the sake of conditions, to expound horizontally.

Now we are like a kingdom without a lord, a land without a ruler,
All beings in the four realms suffer from hunger and famine.
We four assemblies are likewise:
The Heavenly Worthy entrusts us, then returns to his divine form.
Serene and eternally abiding, beyond birth and death,
We are left orphaned, like grieving children.
Having lost the Dharma, lost the Worthy, like withered vines,
We weep and wail, certain of our death.

We only pray that you do not forsake your great compassion,
But universally expound the City of the Treasury of Wisdom of the One Vehicle.

At that time, Haikong, having heard the verse, rose and said:
“Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy, your words are like a parable—
Just as a king raises his many children,
Their forms upright, their hearts vast with love and care,
Teaching them the classics until all are thoroughly versed,
Then the great king entrusts them to govern separate lands and guide their people.

I am now likewise, like a prince,
Having received the complete teachings of the Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy,
I shall return to my divine form.
We bow our heads to the Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy,
Only praying that you do not abandon the beings of the Two Vehicles.
If the Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy remains long in the world,
Expounding the Treasury of Sweet Dew, filling all things,
Then beings will not conceive thoughts of fear or fall into hell.

It is like a man who first studies the arts,
Only to be seized by officials and imprisoned.
His fellow prisoners ask: ‘For what crime have you come to this prison?’
The man replies: ‘I am deeply afflicted.
If I could but escape, I would surely find peace and attain great dharmic power.’

Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy, you are likewise:
For the sake of all beings, dwelling in the city of suffering,
Revealing that suffering is not yet exhausted,
Manifesting in accordance with the inclinations of beings.
The Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy teaches and shows the good seed,
Like a physician who thoroughly understands the properties of medicine,
And again administers wondrous medicine to his child.
All other external students who receive instruction
Cannot perceive it.
Now our Heavenly Worthy is likewise:
Alone, he teaches the profound and subtle treasury of the precious Dharma to the good seed.
How can we not be seen and pitied?
The wondrous Dharma of equality should not be kept secret or hoarded.
Like that physician who teaches only his child and not external students,
One might think the great master’s affection has preferences,
That the Dharma treasure is kept secret,
But the heart of great compassion ultimately has no preferences.
Why is this?
We four assemblies do not see your teachings.
We only pray that you remain long in the world and expound for us.

It is like beings whose bodies suffer illness,
Who abandon the distant, level path and take the perilous road,
Where dangers and hardships abound, and they endure manifold sufferings.
If there were no other person to take pity on them and teach them,
They would be shown the level path.
We four assemblies are likewise:
The Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy, for the sake of great compassion,
Points out to us the treasury of the One Vehicle.
For this reason, we come to understand the equal marks of emptiness and existence.”

At that time, the Heavenly Worthy addressed Haikong, saying:
“Do not let your minds be like those of ordinary people, speaking of preferences.
You should each put aside your sorrow and no longer grieve.
Be diligent and vigorous, maintaining right mindfulness.
If you have any doubts, freely ask and I shall resolve them.
Whether I am empty or not empty, constant or not constant,
Suffering or not suffering, dependent or not dependent,
Abiding or not abiding, departing or not departing, returning or not returning;
Whether suddenly existent or suddenly non-existent, neither constant nor inconstant,
Neither blissful nor non-blissful, neither annihilated nor non-annihilated,
Neither real nor non-real, neither extinguished nor non-extinguished—
Such and other countless aspects within the Dharma,
Whatever you ask, whatever you doubt,
I shall explain for you accordingly,
And I shall also expound for you the flavor of equality.

After I pass away, it will be exceedingly difficult to encounter my manifested form in the world,
Difficult to encounter the body of wisdom, difficult to trust in your own body.
Such difficulties—hard to see, hard to hear.
You have long since perfected the great precepts,
Fulfilled all virtues, and your practice is without flaw,
Thus you have been able to see my form—rare indeed, inconceivable!

Good son, Haikong Treasury of Wisdom,
You have long since departed from the eight difficulties of birth and death,
Attained the vajra body,
And thus encountered me—this should not be in vain.
Good son, in the past, during former kalpas,
I underwent manifold hardships,
And now have attained this unsurpassed fruition of the Dao.
For your sake, I provisionally manifest the abandonment of this body,
And shall return to the divine form of the non-action One Vehicle,
The Dharma city of Haikong, replete with all manner of virtuous treasures,
Which you may take as you will.
Therefore, you shall adorn the true Dharma,
And comprehend the meaning of emptiness.
You shall be of one mind, accumulating manifold virtues,
Encompassing them like the sea, fulfilling the treasury of the heart of wisdom and virtue.
For this reason, you are now named ‘Haikong Treasury of Wisdom of the One Vehicle.’

Good son, it is like merchants who encounter a treasure city,
Personally gather its riches, and return home to become greatly wealthy.
You are likewise:
Having encountered my form and attained the One Vehicle,
Deeply comprehending the treasury of the Dharma,
You accomplish the Dharma body—just so.

At that time, the Heavenly Worthy addressed all the earth immortals:
“Do not let your minds be complacent and conceive thoughts of satisfaction.
Though you students have now left the household life in this Great Vehicle,
Do not covet the ranks of the earth immortals and the like.
Though you four assemblies have donned the robes of great compassion—
Yellow-brown garments and dark headcloths—
Your hearts have not yet been imbued with the treasury of the One Vehicle Dharma.
Though the four assemblies of earth immortals practice gentleness and weakness,
Wandering through famous mountains,
Their hearts have never sought the treasury of the One Vehicle Dharma.
Though they have left the household life, they have not attained the true Dharma;
Though they wear the five flowers, their fetters are not yet severed.

Now, out of great compassion, for the sake of Haikong Treasury,
I expound the true teaching of the One Vehicle.
You four assemblies, while I am still present,
In the midst of the great assembly, I harmoniously resolve
The Dharma-nature of the One Vehicle, true and unshakable.
For this reason, you four assemblies should gather your minds,
Be courageous and vigorous, shatter all fetters and afflictions,
And attain the clarity and purity of the Dharma.”

chunks.original_text: 尔时，地仙闻大哀天尊说是甚深，深有愧想，生大忧苦，身毛寒竖，涕泣交流，头面稽首，作礼尊足，长跪白言：大哀天尊，快说无上，空无我相，止海空愁。 犹如众兽，象王为上。 大哀天尊，亦复如是。 十方国土，於诸天中最为第一。 若有众生生大精进，能除一切三结烦恼、三界无明。 如田农夫，於秋月时，勤耕深地，能除秽草。 我等四众，若有一人生大精进，亦复如是。 虽三界难、常无常苦，以是之故，大哀天尊，虽常无常，反神为最。 犹如国王，知命欲终，恩赦天下，囚击幽挚，悉令得脱，然后舍命。 大哀天尊，亦复如是，教诸我等，一切众生，令得悟解一乘海空，亦复如是。 於是四众得法利益，便大精进，俱起作礼，奉辞而退。 尔时，天尊游於城南，时与诸天真人童子、无鞅数众俱共集会七宝玄台。 尔时，复有十方上圣、无极神王、三十二天大王小王，各有五亿五万五千五百五十人，俱同会法所，一时作礼，瞻仰天尊，依位而坐。 尔时，天尊在於城中七宝玄座，演说一乘海空宝藏。 尔时，城中诸天妙乐，筝筑箜篌，哀婉妙好，音声奇雅； 同时俱作散花烧香，漂漂流流，馨熏无量，内外皆发自然道意。 天尊尔时即便思惟，身心不动，放大光明，普徧十方无极世界。 地狱之中，饿鬼众生，无不睹见。 於是四众若人非人，一切众生，同在一座，各得利益。 一切根性染着光相，心自觉悟，发大精进，一心谛听。 尔时，海空智藏从座而起，更整衣服，前进作礼，白天尊言：大德仁者，我自随侍，无数劫来，未有今日。 大哀天尊放大光明，徧於十方，无不普周，天上天下，一切众生，若人非人，各得利益。 未审天尊云何顿尔奇特之相，利益一切。 尔时，天尊发大慈心，答海空智藏言：善哉善哉，善男子，各还本坐，当为子等分别解说。 善男子往昔过去，吾以大慈演说一乘秘密宝藏，广为天人开张法教，普度一切得受真道，敬慎三品，履於十方五亿诸天。 开校大有，化度众生，前劫后劫，随方化度； 观空相空，都无所着，禀空定相，都无所相。 以是因缘，我今当还无形之地，自然同根。 海空智藏，汝可及时请论要义。 我观众生住烦恼城，深着恶相，各自愁煎，故为哀愍，出身应现。 非烦恼身，非五浊身。 汝等当知一乘海空观於众生，分别说法。 於是天尊欲宣此义，而说偈言： 海空不思议，无形自然应。 一切诸众生，各从烟煴起。 不失生因缘，因缘各有对，历劫苦绵绵，难离亦难免。 着相难解脱，随劫如轮环。 我於宝城舍，思惟说一乘。 众生不同故，慈心发哀怜。 海空城难入，故重说妙言。 了见诸道士，自然得道真。 集见诸道士，勤学入空城。 道士修仙道，一生非复生。 仙道集亘长，无碍亦无间。 缅缅大仙王，游乐於太玄。 我今当过去，寂灭无碍身。 众苦自有缘，贤者乃知真。 尔时，天尊说偈颂已，告海空言：善男子，海空智藏，汝今久已宿植德本，登於上道，名称平等，犹如大海，空纳众流。 汝今亦尔，随应下方，为诸众生立大宝藏，不可思议。 我观汝心，有善方术，欲念众生，医治有病。 善男子，当来众生常所忧愁，有大身病，心病、腹病、头病、手病，随汝所治。 吾当反神，还乎无为不动之地。
chunks.translated_text:
At that time, the earth immortals, hearing the Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy expound these profound teachings, were filled with shame and remorse. Overcome with deep sorrow, their body hairs stood on end, tears streaming down their faces. They bowed their heads to the ground, prostrating at the Worthy’s feet, and knelt to address him, saying: “Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy, swiftly proclaim the supreme teaching of emptiness and the absence of self, to assuage the sorrows of the Haikong Treasury. Just as among all beasts, the elephant king is supreme, so too is the Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy foremost among all the heavens across the ten directions. If there are beings who arouse great diligence, they can eradicate the three fetters of affliction and the ignorance of the three realms—just as a farmer, in the autumn month, diligently plows the deep earth to remove noxious weeds. If even one among us four assemblies arouses such great diligence, it is likewise. Though the sufferings of the three realms—whether constant or inconstant—are difficult to endure, for this reason, Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy, though the constant and inconstant abide, the reversal of spirit is supreme. Just as a king, knowing his life is nearing its end, mercifully pardons all under heaven, releasing prisoners from their bonds and shackles, allowing them to go free before he departs this life, so too does the Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy teach us and all beings, enabling us to awaken to the One Vehicle of the Haikong Treasury. Thus, the four assemblies, having received the benefit of the Dharma, aroused great diligence. Together, they rose, paid homage, and took their leave.

At that time, the Heavenly Worthy wandered to the south of the city, where he gathered with an innumerable assembly of heavenly perfected ones, youths, and divine youths upon a seven-jeweled mystic terrace. Then, from the ten directions, supreme sages, boundless divine kings, and the thirty-two great and lesser heavenly kings, each accompanied by five hundred fifty-five thousand five hundred fifty followers, assembled at the Dharma site. As one, they paid homage, gazing upon the Heavenly Worthy, and took their seats in due order.

At that time, the Heavenly Worthy, seated upon a seven-jeweled mystic throne within the city, expounded the One Vehicle of the Haikong Treasury. Within the city, the heavenly musicians played zithers, zhu, and konghou, their melodies plaintive and exquisite, their sounds rare and refined. Together, they scattered flowers and burned incense, their fragrance wafting and flowing, perfuming the boundless expanse, both within and without, naturally evoking the Daoist intent. Then, the Heavenly Worthy, in deep contemplation, his body and mind unmoving, emitted a great radiance that pervaded the ten directions and the boundless worlds. Even in the hells and among the hungry ghosts, none failed to behold it. Thus, the four assemblies—whether human or non-human—and all beings, though seated together, each received benefit. All whose faculties were stained by attachment to the light’s appearance awakened in their hearts, aroused great diligence, and single-mindedly listened with reverence.

At that time, Haikong Treasury of Wisdom rose from his seat, adjusted his robes, stepped forward, and bowed to the Heavenly Worthy, saying: “Virtuous One, I have attended upon you for countless kalpas, yet never before has there been a day like this. The Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy has emitted a great radiance that pervades the ten directions without exception, universally encompassing all—heaven above and heaven below, all beings, whether human or non-human, each receiving benefit. I wonder, Heavenly Worthy, what extraordinary sign this is, benefiting all beings in such a manner.”

Then, the Heavenly Worthy, moved by great compassion, replied to Haikong Treasury of Wisdom: “Excellent, excellent, good son. Return each to your seat, and I shall explain this for you. Good son, in the past, I expounded the One Vehicle of the secret treasury with great compassion, broadly unfolding the Dharma teachings for gods and humans, universally delivering all to receive the true Dao. Reverently observing the three grades, they traversed the ten directions and the five billion heavens. I opened the great kalpas, transforming and delivering beings, in past kalpas and future kalpas, adapting to each realm. Contemplating emptiness and the emptiness of appearances, utterly unattached, they received the samādhi of emptiness, yet without any fixed appearance. For this reason, I shall now return to the realm of formlessness, naturally united in root.

Haikong Treasury of Wisdom, you should now request the essential teachings in a timely manner. I observe that beings dwell in the city of afflictions, deeply attached to evil appearances, each tormented by their own sorrows. Thus, out of compassion, I manifest a responsive form—not a body of afflictions, nor a body of the five turbidities. You should know that the One Vehicle of the Haikong Treasury observes beings and teaches the Dharma accordingly.”

Then, the Heavenly Worthy, wishing to proclaim this meaning, spoke in verse:

The Haikong Treasury is inconceivable,
Formless, naturally responsive.
All beings arise from the wisp of smoke,
Never losing the causes and conditions of birth.
Causes and conditions each have their counterparts,
Enduring kalpas of suffering, unceasing,
Difficult to escape, difficult to avoid.
Attachment to appearances makes liberation hard,
Following the kalpas like a turning wheel.
In the jeweled city, I abide,
Contemplating and expounding the One Vehicle.
Because beings differ,
My compassionate heart arouses pity.
The Haikong city is hard to enter,
Thus I repeatedly expound these wondrous words.
Those who see the Daoists
Naturally attain the true Dao.
Gathering to see the Daoists,
Diligently study and enter the city of emptiness.
Daoists cultivate the immortal Dao,
In one lifetime, no rebirth.
The immortal Dao gathers and endures,
Unobstructed and without interval.
The distant great immortal king
Roams and delights in the Great Mystery.
I shall now depart,
My body of quiescence and unobstructedness.
All sufferings have their causes,
Only the wise know the truth.

Then, the Heavenly Worthy, having spoken these verses, addressed Haikong Treasury, saying: “Good son, Haikong Treasury of Wisdom, you have long since planted the roots of virtue in past lives, ascending the supreme Dao. Your fame is equal and impartial, like the great sea that receives all streams. You are likewise—responding to the lower realms, establishing the great treasury for all beings, inconceivable in its vastness. I observe your heart, possessing skillful methods, desiring to heal the illnesses of beings. Good son, in the future, beings will be constantly afflicted by great bodily diseases—ailments of the mind, the abdomen, the head, the hands—treat them as you see fit. I shall now return my spirit to the realm of non-action and immutability.”

chunks.original_text: 尔时，海空闻是说已，心自忧愁，顶礼着地，泣泪稽首，白天尊言：云何一旦逝於世间，还乎反神寂灭之地？ 唯愿天尊发大慈风，普示一切，若人非人，普知育养，济拔众生出烦恼城，安隐宝藏。 是诸众生，重见病者，一时释散。 以大法雨，雨於一切烦恼众生，开导通有，是所不辞。 尔时，天尊含笑而言，即答海空：善哉男子，汝能立大三界舟航，为诸天人一切众生、无极世界苦恼众生、蠢动之类作大桥梁，度诸众生入梅空城，安慰众生死形之地。 又告海空：汝可思惟一乘海空秘密宝藏，为他演说，往於十方无极世界。 如是诸国，不可思议。 精进踊跃，海空智藏，一切众生钝根难悟，不知一切若人非人，皆归於空，空无我相，以无我相，妄生分别。 於是海空即便起立，更复白言：大哀天尊，云何一切是诸众生皆当空尽，既是空尽，云何有於罪福苦乐？ 於是天尊答海空言：善男子，汝等当知一切众生皆当归空； 以归空故，妄造众罪。 於罪不空，是名罪苦； 於福不空，是名福乐。 心染罪福，有苦有乐，有憎有爱。 以是因缘，故有罪福。 若有一人观於我身，我身既空，诸法亦空，罪相云何，在何方所？ 若在烦恼，烦恼相空； 若在於福，福相亦空。 以是当知罪空福空，罪福空故，故名空空。 善男子，汝能善化，顺彼应身，故名海空； 使诸众生精思勤念，读诵《一乘海空宝藏》一字一句、一行一偈，专心存念，当知是人是天中天，恒值海空一乘空义，恒坐海空一乘空城。 善男子，若有众生，知我无形，自然同根，当知是人从‘天上来，得仙道满，一切国人，各共归依，善言赞叹，名曰长乐不动之国。 复生海空智藏言，善男子，若有众生，生於下方，住烦恼城，知身是苦，发心告诸人民：我等众生同住烦恼恶毒火城，云何得出，离生死城？ 得入海空一乘法城，是长乐国，无诸烦恼、安隐之地。 尔时，众生闻是语已，各共惶惧，便发念言：我等云何生在下土，烦恼城中，三毒火难？ 云何得生，往到彼国？ 彼大安乐，隔碍海水。 云何而往，当到彼国？ 尔时，众中有一人曰：我曾见彼海中三船，大船可载无量数人，中船可载百千万人，小船可载十千万人。 以此三船有大神力，不畏风浪，篙橹柂棹，皆新坚固。 我等自往海水船中，泛越渚侧，当到彼岸，甚大欢乐。 尔时，四众得闻是语，心大欢喜，各各庄持。 一千二百四十万人齐心欲去，往到彼岸。 尔时，复有不去之徒五千万人，各共别送，诣於海边，同别辞去。 分别既竟， 尔时，众中有五万人即上大船，有九万人复上中船，有十万人复上小船，各随其意上船毕竟，举帆便发，风调顺流，须臾千里。 尔时，海岸不去之徒皆笑叹曰：是等群愚，云何取死，入於大海，望至彼岸，宁灭身命，云何可至？ 尔时，乘船，泛舟而往，浮景而行。 然此海中有大洲屿，於洲屿中复有国土。 於是三船同到一国，国大丰有，自然饮食，国中人民，皆生善心，金银七宝以为城舍。 尔时，小船各共言曰：我所乘船，船力微弱，不堪复行，计我本国出十万里，此国膏粱於我乃足，愿住此国。 於是小船便住此国。 中船、大船，举帆复去。 复经一国，其土平正，七宝满国，自然衣食，无有中夭，寿得其年。
chunks.translated_text:
At that time, Haikong, having heard these words, grew sorrowful in his heart. Prostrating himself with his head to the ground, he wept and bowed, then addressed the Heavenly Worthy, saying: “How can you suddenly depart from the world and return to the realm of stillness and extinction? I only beseech the Heavenly Worthy to stir the great wind of compassion, universally revealing all—whether human or non-human—so that all may know nurturance and sustenance, delivering beings from the city of afflictions and securing them in the treasury of peace. May all beings, upon seeing the sick, be instantly released. With the great rain of the Dharma, shower all afflicted beings, guiding and illuminating all existence—this I shall never refuse.”

Then, the Heavenly Worthy smiled and replied to Haikong: “Excellent, good son! You are able to establish the great vessel spanning the Three Realms, serving as the great bridge for all gods, humans, and beings in the boundless worlds—those suffering in distress and all moving creatures—ferrying them into the City of Plum Void, comforting those in the realm of death and form. Furthermore, I instruct you, Haikong: contemplate the secret treasury of the One Vehicle, the *Haikong*, and expound it for others, traveling to the boundless worlds in the ten directions. Such lands are beyond conception. With diligence and joy, Haikong Treasury of Wisdom, all beings—dull-rooted and slow to awaken—do not comprehend that all, whether human or non-human, return to emptiness. Emptiness is without the mark of self; yet through the absence of self, false distinctions arise.”

Thereupon, Haikong rose and again addressed the Heavenly Worthy: “Greatly compassionate Heavenly Worthy, how is it that all these beings shall be utterly empty? If all is empty, how then can there be sin and merit, suffering and joy?”

The Heavenly Worthy replied to Haikong: “Good son, you should know that all beings shall return to emptiness. Precisely because they return to emptiness, they falsely create manifold sins. Where sin is not empty, this is called the suffering of sin; where merit is not empty, this is called the joy of merit. The mind, stained by sin and merit, knows suffering and joy, hatred and love. Through these causes and conditions, sin and merit arise. If one observes one’s own body—since the body is empty, all dharmas are also empty—where then is the form of sin, and in what place does it reside? If it resides in affliction, the mark of affliction is empty; if it resides in merit, the mark of merit is also empty. Thus, know that sin is empty and merit is empty; since sin and merit are empty, this is called ‘emptiness of emptiness.’ Good son, you are able to skillfully transform, adapting to the responsive forms of beings—hence the name *Haikong*. Cause all beings to diligently contemplate and recite the *One Vehicle Treasury of Haikong*, word by word, line by line, verse by verse, with single-minded devotion. Know that such a person is the Heaven among Heavens, ever abiding in the meaning of the One Vehicle’s emptiness, ever dwelling in the City of Emptiness of the One Vehicle. Good son, if there are beings who know my formless nature, naturally sharing the same root, know that such a person comes ‘from the heavens above,’ having fulfilled the immortal Dao. All people of every land will together take refuge and praise them with kind words, calling it the Land of Eternal Joy and Immovability.”

Again, the Heavenly Worthy addressed Haikong Treasury, saying: “Good son, if there are beings born in the lower realms, dwelling in the city of afflictions, who recognize the body as suffering and awaken their minds to tell the people: ‘We beings all dwell together in the fiery city of afflictions, poisoned by the three toxins—how can we escape and leave the city of birth and death? How can we enter the Dharma-city of the One Vehicle, the Land of Eternal Joy, a place without afflictions, a realm of peace?’”

At that time, the beings, having heard these words, were each filled with dread and thought to themselves: “How is it that we were born in the lower lands, within the city of afflictions, tormented by the fire of the three poisons? How can we be reborn and reach that land? That land of great peace is separated by vast seas. How can we cross and arrive there?”

Then, one among the assembly said: “I have seen three ships in that sea: the great ship can carry countless beings, the medium ship can carry hundreds of thousands, and the small ship can carry tens of thousands. These three ships possess great spiritual power, unafraid of wind and waves, with oars and rudders all newly sturdy. If we ourselves board these ships and sail across the waters, we shall reach the other shore with great joy.”

Thereupon, the four assemblies, having heard these words, rejoiced greatly and each prepared themselves. One million two hundred forty thousand people, with one mind, desired to depart for the other shore. Yet there were fifty million who chose not to go, each bidding farewell at the seashore. After parting, fifty thousand among the assembly boarded the great ship, ninety thousand boarded the medium ship, and one hundred thousand boarded the small ship, each according to their preference, finally embarking. Raising the sails, the wind was favorable, and in an instant, they traveled a thousand miles.

Then, those who remained on the shore laughed and sighed, saying: “How foolish are these people! Why seek death by entering the great sea, hoping to reach the other shore? How could they possibly arrive, even at the cost of their lives?”

At that time, those aboard the ships sailed forth, gliding upon the waters. Now, within this sea were great islands, and upon these islands were lands. The three ships arrived together at one such land—a vast and abundant country with natural food and drink. The people of this land were all of good heart, and their cities and dwellings were made of gold, silver, and the seven treasures.

Then, those on the small ship said to one another: “The ship we ride is weak in strength and cannot sail further. We have already traveled a hundred thousand miles from our homeland, and this land’s abundance is sufficient for us. We wish to remain here.” Thus, the small ship stayed in this land. The medium and great ships raised their sails and continued onward.

They passed another land, level and just, filled with the seven treasures, with natural clothing and food. None died prematurely, and all lived out their years.

chunks.original_text: 便即命过，魂升天堂，身体不灰。 乘中船人复谓言曰：我所乘船，船力微弱，不堪复进，且住此国，功德受报，於我以足。 请止此国。 於是便住，乘大船人举帆而去，往到彼岸极大乐国。 国土人民，黄金为地，碧玉为阶，七宝行树，上生甘果，七宝宫殿，寿命长远，与道合德。 於是受生，得道自然。 尔时，天尊告海空言：善男子，向所说言三船行人，或近或远。 卿意云何？ 於是海空即便答言：不审天尊向所说言，三船载力可有大小？ 而於水行复有力之，或近或远，是事不然。 云何三船一时举帆，行有远近？ 不审天尊於意云何？ 尔时，天尊答海空言：善男子，我说言三船行者，是事云何？ 善男子，行有精赢，有高有下，有远有近，有大有小。 所以者何？
chunks.translated_text:
Then, as their lives ended, their souls ascended to heaven, and their bodies did not turn to ash.

Those on the medium ship said to one another: “The ship we ride is weak in strength and cannot advance further. Let us remain in this land, where the rewards of our merit are sufficient for us.” Thus, they begged to stay in this land, and so they remained. Those on the great ship raised their sails and departed, arriving at the farther shore—the Land of Utmost Bliss. In this land, the people’s ground was of gold, their steps of jade, and rows of seven-jeweled trees bore sweet fruit. Their palaces were of the seven treasures, their lifespans long, and their virtue in harmony with the Dao. There, they were reborn and attained the Dao by nature.

Then, the Heavenly Venerable addressed Haikong, saying: “Good son, as for the three ships and their travelers of whom I spoke—some near, some far—what do you think?”

Thereupon, Haikong replied: “I do not understand, Heavenly Venerable, the meaning of your earlier words. Do the three ships truly differ in their carrying capacity? And yet, when sailing upon the waters, do they also differ in strength? How can it be that some travel near and some far? How is it that the three ships, raising their sails at the same time, arrive at different distances? What is the Heavenly Venerable’s intent?”

Then, the Heavenly Venerable answered Haikong, saying: “Good son, what do you make of my words about the three ships’ journey? Good son, the path may be strong or weak, high or low, far or near, great or small. Why is this so?”

Their souls drift and wander, cut off from the root of human rebirth. Thus do all the sages, moved by great compassion, divide the One into Three, guiding beings along separate paths, that they may escape suffering and gradually enter the Great Vehicle. Hence the distinction of great lands, middle lands, and small lands—some near, some far. The great ship ascends the cloud-bound path.

My heart holds the overflowing virtue of the Dao,
Through kalpas I rescue from calamity’s causes.
The middle ship plays amidst the clouds’ net,
Its mind at ease, universally embracing.

Yet may attain self-benefit through care.
Small and middle lack wisdom and awakening,

At that time, among the assembly there was an immortal named Miao Si, who rose from his seat, bowed his head to the ground in reverence, and addressed the Heavenly Venerable, saying: "Great Compassionate Heavenly Venerable, why do meritorious virtues and practices vary in weight, some great and some small, with corresponding differences in karmic reward? What is the meaning of this? Can one awaken to the causes and conditions behind it?"

At that time, the Heavenly Venerable replied to Miao Si, saying: "Good son, as for meritorious virtue, it arises from wisdom in practice, opening the gates of all dharmas and revealing the Dao to all beings—whether human or non-human. Contemplating the single-vehicle treasury of the sea of emptiness, one attains decisive insight, emptily comprehending all dharmas across the boundless lands and worlds of the ten directions, seeing them as clearly as the palm of one’s hand, with nothing left unseen.

Good son, if there are beings who single-mindedly perform prostrations, meditating on the wisdom-treasury of the single-vehicle sea of emptiness, forgetting sleep and food, fasting past noon, and upholding the precepts without fail—

Good son, it is like a filial son whose parents have died: embracing the coffin, he wails in grief, beating his breast and crying out to heaven, moving all within the kingdom, human and non-human alike, to weep with him. Thereupon, his parents immediately revive. Then, all the children rejoice together, leaping with boundless joy. My joy is likewise thus.

If there are beings who contemplate the wisdom-treasury of the single-vehicle sea of emptiness and expound it to others, forgetting to eat, I will guard and protect them, never abandoning my original vow, and my joy will be boundless. It is also like the filial son who does not lose his parents—so too is it thus.

Good son, if there are beings whose hearts abide in gentle yielding, whose bodies and minds endure humiliation, whose speech avoids evil, whose six senses are pure, and who do not join with humans, devas, or any beings to create an ‘evil city’ or accumulate wicked karma—it is like a compassionate mother who nurtures her beloved child, holding him close and never parting from her lap, always guarding and protecting him, never allowing him to quarrel with others. So too do I guard and protect their body, mind, speech, and intention.

Good son, if there are beings who practice great generosity, giving away their household wealth, kingdoms, wives, children, beloved kin, the seven treasures, and all precious things, bestowing them upon others and scattering blessings to all beings of the ten directions, human and non-human alike—it is like sweet rain that moistens all, so that every plant and tree receives its benefit. My compassionate giving is likewise thus."

At that time, Miao Si and the fourfold assembly, having heard these words, gained great dharma benefit. They each resolved to cultivate diligently, rose together, and approached the Heavenly Venerable. With single-minded devotion, they bowed in reverence, took their leave, and departed.

Thus concludes *Scroll Eight of the Heavenly Venerable’s Single-Vehicle Treasury of the Sea of Emptiness and Wisdom*.

**The Chapter on Abandoning and Receiving**

At that time, the Heavenly Venerable addressed King Good-Seed: "Good man, great king and elder, you have relinquished your wisdom and wealth, come from afar, and entreated me to expound the *Single-Vehicle Treasury of the Sea of Emptiness and Wisdom*, abiding in the jeweled city within your kingdom upon the seat of the true adept.

"Good man, great king, having heard the true adept of the *Treasury of the Sea of Emptiness and Wisdom* inquire after illness, how does it appear to you?"

Thereupon, King Good-Seed and the elders, having heard the Great Compassionate Heavenly Venerable speak these words, rose from their seats, prostrated at the Venerable’s feet, and addressed the Heavenly Venerable: "That true adept from afar possesses profound wisdom, making repayment difficult. He fully comprehends the marks of dharma and is unhindered in eloquence. All the immortals and adepts have resolved the *Single-Vehicle Treasury of the Sea of Emptiness and Wisdom*, and none fail to enter the gate of wisdom. Moreover, he subdues the hosts of external paths and demonic forces, manifesting divine powers and skillful means—all have attained liberation. His wisdom is unfathomable, wondrous and subtle, rare indeed, rare indeed!

"The Great Compassionate Heavenly Venerable, for the sake of all beings, instructs the true adept to dwell in the jeweled city and expound the *Single-Vehicle Treasury of the Sea of Emptiness and Wisdom*. At that time, all the disciples, the people of the world, the great kings, and the elders together aroused wholesome minds, relinquishing their bodies, wisdom, and wealth—houses, mansions, servants, and attendants—all were scattered in offering. Now, as that true adept expounds the Dharma, among those seated in faith are over eight thousand true adepts, seven hundred immortals, three hundred great kings, and hundreds of millions of devas and humans—both men and women—all following in attendance. Hearing the essential teachings of the *Single-Vehicle Treasury of the Sea of Emptiness and Wisdom*, they become great bridges and Dharma stairways.

"Then, the true adept and his disciples employed their spiritual power, and within the jeweled city, all the palaces to the left and right became utterly empty. At that time, the true adept sat in the empty city, having removed all possessions, resting only upon a jeweled couch due to illness. All his disciples—both human and non-human—gathered around, gazing upon him with tears streaming down in a hundred rivulets, sighing in unison: 'The Great Compassionate True Adept abandons us, leaving us exposed and desolate! Alas, the true adept forsakes us, resting due to illness. Now we reflect: from whence does the great master’s illness arise? Can it be cured? If it may be healed, we, his disciples, would rather relinquish our bodies and lives to restore the great master, that he may accomplish for us the *Single-Vehicle Treasury of the Sea of Emptiness and Wisdom*, comforting us and abiding in the great jeweled city, where we may hear his teachings.'

"At that time, the *Treasury of the Sea of Emptiness and Wisdom* proclaimed: 'My illness arises for the sake of all beings. It is not the mark of illness, yet it is called illness; it is not the mark of seeing, yet it is called seeing; it is not the mark of emptiness, yet it is called emptiness; it is not the mark of speech, yet it is called speech. Our minds remain doubtful and unclear—how is this so? We only pray that the Great Compassionate One, for our sake, will distinguish and explain it.'

"Thereupon, the Heavenly Venerable, with great compassion, replied to King Good-Seed: 'Good man, great king and elder, as you have said, the true adept of the *Sea of Emptiness* fully comprehends this mark of illness—there is no dharma of illness beyond it; he fully comprehends this mark of abiding—there is no dharma of abiding beyond it; he fully comprehends this mark of emptiness—there is no dharma of emptiness beyond it.'"

chunks.original_text: 一了此说相，更无法说； 了此安相，更无法安； 了此去相，更无法去。 所以者何？ 疾无所从，住无所安，空无有着。 若有法者，视之不见； 若空法者，随之则有。 以是之故，住者无所置，去者无所至。 今所疾者，更无可疾； 今所住者，更无可住； 今所空者，更无可空； 今所置者，更无可置。 汝等大王善心受持，自当得解。 於是众中善种大王闻说是已，心大欢喜，顶礼尊足，白天尊言：如是说者，今海空疾宁可医治，疗之有损，不增病不？ 大哀天尊，众中无量真仙童子、地仙道士殷勤致问，海空真士而今疾者，何所因起？ 云何当灭，尽其疾因？ 令众欢喜，同发善心，好乐观听一乘海空智慧宝藏。 尔时，天尊答善种王：善男子，汝等问者，言海空疾从何因起？ 善男子，海空疾者从众缘起，是故有病。 若诸众生得不病者，海空真士亦复不病。 何以故？ 海空智藏为众生故，入生死身。 有生死身，则有病因。 若诸众生得离病者，是则海空无复有病。 善男子，譬如慈母，唯有一子，其子得病，父母亦病； 其子病愈，父母亦愈。 海空真士，亦复如是。 今海空者於诸众生，爱之若子。 以是因缘，众生有病，海空亦病。 善男子，言海空病何所因起。 汝等大王，我今思惟，海空疾者从大慈起。 於是众中善种大王闻此语已，白天尊言：大哀天尊，云何海空智藏真士住宝城中，城空无有床座之坐？ 我今思惟，甚大惶怖。 於是天尊答善种王：善哉善哉，善男子，言城空者，三清玉京，长乐国土，亦复空虚。 善种大王又复白言：如是所说，以何为空，而云空虚？ 天尊答言：以空为空。 又复问言：空何以空？ 天尊答言：空无分别。 何以故？ 分别亦空，故言空空。 善种又言：空分别不？ 天尊答言：分别亦空。 又问：空无分别，空於何法？ 答言：空於法相，空於六尘。 六尘既空，法相亦空。 善种又问：法相云何？ 答言：即法相者，即是解脱，是解脱者即是法相。 以是之故，法相既空，解脱亦空。 又言：云何解脱？ 答言：是烦恼者即是解脱，是解脱者即是烦恼。 解脱既空，烦恼亦空。 善种又言：是烦恼者，即是病者，而非病耶？ 若是病者，病从何来？ 为从身来，为非身来？ 若从身者，身法既有烦恼，云何而云为空？ 天尊答言：我说病者，即是烦恼，烦恼既空，病法亦空。 病法既空，身法亦空。 何以故？ 烦恼身者，如幻如梦。 以是因缘，以空为空。 善种又言：地水火风四大之中，何大是身？ 答言：烦恼身者，非地大生，不离地大； 水、火、风大，亦复如是。 一切众生烦恼身者，从四大起，以之为病。 是故真士随之为病。 於是善种得闻说已，即起作礼，赞叹一乘海空智藏，是我大师，为我辈说言有病，诸行无常，身法无我，不说海空厌离於身； 说身有苦，不说常乐玄都玉京，教导三乘，为诸众生作大桥梁，度生死海。 於空城中托身有疾，哀彼众生，令识宿世亿劫中苦，当念饶益一切众生，修弘福田，念於众生勿令忧恼，劝助众生勤行精进； 作大医王，疗治众生一切病根，慰喻众生，以疾而 卧。 尔时，海空智藏告善种王：汝等勿疑我身疾者，而言无疾。 今我疾者，皆前世因，妄想颠倒，诸烦恼生，无有实法，惟之为疾。

"He fully comprehends this mark of speech—there is no dharma of speech beyond it; he fully comprehends this mark of tranquility—there is no dharma of tranquility beyond it; he fully comprehends this mark of departure—there is no dharma of departure beyond it. Why is this so? Illness arises from nowhere; abiding finds no resting place; emptiness has no attachment. If there were a dharma, it would be unseen upon inspection; if it were an empty dharma, it would exist upon following it. For this reason, that which abides has nowhere to be placed, and that which departs has nowhere to arrive. Now, what is called illness has nothing to be ill; what is called abiding has nothing to abide; what is called emptiness has nothing to be empty; what is placed has nothing to be placed. Great kings, hold these words with a virtuous mind, and you shall attain understanding."

Thereupon, the great King Good-Seed among the assembly, having heard these words, rejoiced greatly in his heart. He bowed at the Venerable One’s feet and addressed the Heavenly Venerable: "If this is so, can the illness of the *Sea of Emptiness* be treated? Would healing it cause harm, or would it not worsen the affliction?"

The Heavenly Venerable of Great Compassion, amidst the boundless assembly of true immortals, divine youths, and earthbound Daoists, was earnestly questioned: "What is the cause of the illness of the *Sea of Emptiness* adept? How may it be extinguished, and its causes exhausted? May this bring joy to the assembly, that all may arouse a virtuous mind and delight in hearing the treasury of the single vehicle of *Sea of Emptiness* wisdom."

Thereupon, the Heavenly Venerable replied to King Good-Seed: "Good man, you ask from whence the illness of the *Sea of Emptiness* arises. Good man, the illness of the *Sea of Emptiness* arises from the convergence of conditions, and thus there is affliction. If all beings were free from illness, the adept of the *Sea of Emptiness* would likewise be free from illness. Why is this so? The treasury of *Sea of Emptiness* wisdom enters the body of birth and death for the sake of beings. With the body of birth and death, there is the cause of illness. If all beings were free from illness, then the *Sea of Emptiness* would no longer suffer affliction. Good man, it is like a compassionate mother with but one child: if the child falls ill, the parents also fall ill; if the child recovers, the parents also recover. The adept of the *Sea of Emptiness* is likewise. Now, the *Sea of Emptiness* loves all beings as a child. For this reason, when beings are ill, the *Sea of Emptiness* is also ill. Good man, you ask from whence the illness of the *Sea of Emptiness* arises. Great kings, I now reflect: the illness of the *Sea of Emptiness* arises from great compassion."

Thereupon, King Good-Seed in the assembly, having heard these words, addressed the Heavenly Venerable: "Heavenly Venerable of Great Compassion, how is it that the adept of the *Sea of Emptiness* treasury of wisdom dwells in the jeweled city, yet the city is empty, without even a seat or throne? I now reflect upon this with great trepidation."

Thereupon, the Heavenly Venerable replied to King Good-Seed: "Excellent, excellent, good man! You speak of the city’s emptiness—the Three Clarities’ Jade Capital and the Land of Eternal Bliss are likewise empty and void. King Good-Seed again addressed him: "If this is what is said, by what is it empty, that it is called empty and void?" The Heavenly Venerable replied: "It is empty of emptiness." He further asked: "By what is emptiness empty?" The Heavenly Venerable replied: "Emptiness has no distinctions. Why is this so? Distinctions are also empty, and thus it is called emptiness of emptiness." Good-Seed again asked: "Does emptiness distinguish or not?" The Heavenly Venerable replied: "Distinctions are also empty." He further asked: "If emptiness has no distinctions, of what dharma is it empty?" He replied: "It is empty of dharma-marks, empty of the six dusts. Since the six dusts are empty, dharma-marks are also empty." Good-Seed again asked: "What are dharma-marks?" He replied: "Dharma-marks are precisely liberation, and liberation is precisely dharma-marks. For this reason, since dharma-marks are empty, liberation is also empty." He further asked: "What is liberation?" He replied: "Afflictions are precisely liberation, and liberation is precisely afflictions. Since liberation is empty, afflictions are also empty." Good-Seed again asked: "If afflictions are illness, are they not illness? If they are illness, from whence does illness come? Does it come from the body, or not from the body? If it comes from the body, since the body-dharma has afflictions, how can it be called empty?" The Heavenly Venerable replied: "What I call illness is precisely afflictions; since afflictions are empty, the dharma of illness is also empty. Since the dharma of illness is empty, the dharma of the body is also empty. Why is this so? The afflicted body is like an illusion, like a dream. For this reason, it is empty of emptiness." Good-Seed again asked: "Among the four great elements—earth, water, fire, and wind—which great element is the body?" He replied: "The afflicted body is not born from the earth great, yet it does not depart from the earth great. It is likewise with the water, fire, and wind greats. The afflicted bodies of all beings arise from the four greats, and this is called illness. Thus, the true adept follows and is ill with them."

Thereupon, Good-Seed, having heard these words, rose and bowed, praising the single vehicle of the *Sea of Emptiness* treasury of wisdom: "This is my great teacher, who speaks to us of illness, that all conditioned things are impermanent, that the body-dharma is without self, and does not speak of the *Sea of Emptiness* as weary of the body; who speaks of the body’s suffering, and does not speak of the eternal bliss of the Jade Capital of the Mysterious Metropolis; who instructs the three vehicles and acts as a great bridge for all beings, ferrying them across the sea of birth and death. Dwelling in the empty city, he takes on illness in his body, pitying those beings, that they may recognize the suffering of countless kalpas in past lives. He urges the cultivation of vast merit, that all beings may be benefited, and that none may be caused distress. He exhorts and aids all beings to diligently practice vigor. As the great king of physicians, he treats the roots of all illness in beings, comforting and consoling them, lying ill in their stead."

Thereupon, the treasury of *Sea of Emptiness* wisdom addressed King Good-Seed: "Do not doubt that my body is ill, yet there is no illness. The illness I now have arises from past-life causes—deluded thoughts, inverted views, and the arising of afflictions. There is no substantial dharma in it, yet it is called illness."

chunks.original_text: 所以者何？ 四大合故，假名为身； 四大无主，身亦无着。 今我疾者，皆由着身，是故於身不应生着。 善种王既知病本，即除我想及烦恼想，当灭法想。 汝等大王应作是念，但以众法合成此身，我身之身，起唯法起，灭唯法灭。 此法身者，各不相知，起时不言，我起汝灭； 灭时不言，我灭汝起。 我念众生，亦复如是。 善种大王，汝等当知，应作是念。 此法身者，亦是颠倒。 是我身者，即是大患。 汝等应当厌离此身，云何为离我所？ 离我所者，即离二法； 离二法者，不念内外，诸法平等。 云何平等？ 我等常乐，常乐清 净，内外无我，我亦清净。 此二等者，悉皆空空。 以何为空？ 但以名字，名字故空。 如此二法，无次定性。 得是平等，无有余病，唯有空病。 空病亦空，了空病故，是我有疾。 今我病者，无受而受，说身无常，法相不灭。 而取证信，故设有身，普念众生，发大慈心，说一乘藏。 调伏我身，亦当调伏一切众生，除种种病。 今我说病，为断众生攀缘病本，断病本故，则无所得。 若无所得，则断攀缘。 诸根若尽，是我无病。 善种大王得闻说已，稽首作礼，长跪赞言：善哉善哉，大哀真士，为断我故，作如是说，调伏我身，亦当调伏一切众生老病死苦。 若不如是，我等众生生无惠利，烦恼所缚。 海空真士为我说者，譬如法胜，乃可为勇，亦复能除老病死苦，得住城中，彼说我听。 海空真士，亦复如是，为我有疾，而云有病。 我身病者，非真非有。 海空智藏，亦复如是，非真非有。 若有众生，观此病者，时不起爱见，如是人者，是海空藏，久已离於生死病身。 何以故？ 海空智藏久已断除微尘烦恼，而起大慈，为爱悲者，则於生死者疲厌心，托疾而 卧。 若有众生能厌离心，随有所爱，如是之人，在在所生，不为爱见之所覆也。 得了法相，所生无击，复能智慧，为诸众生说法解系，亦如海空所说一乘，有系皆解，脱身有系，能解他系，自他之系，悉皆清 净。 若有众生贪爱着善味，是海空击於系中想，烦恼无主，身亦无我。 如是念者，是方便生，是海空解。 善种大王说是语已，瞻仰尊颜，作礼而退。 於是海空闻善种说，心大欢喜，告善种王：善哉善哉，善男子，汝等上士是我真子，智慧甚深，才辩无碍，能了法相。 是我大师，智慧难思，过於我说。 我今思惟，善种大王名不虚耶，善能建立，三界种留，故名善种。 善男子，汝当谛听，分别为说。 善男子，云何方便而为系者？ 以着见心，小乘小见，装褫三宝。 七宝宫殿，成就其身，而自调伏，化诸众生，俱行有法，於空无相，作法中，种种装褫。 如是人者，是方便系。 云何而为方便解者？ 不以爱见，而作爱身，庄严微妙，成就众生，俱了一乘海空智藏，安住不动，证空非空，说有非有，以方便力，於空无相，化作法中，亦导众生，令其调伏，厌离其身，不受诸爱。 如是人者，是方便解。 善种大王，若有一人有疾而 卧，汝等应当作如是念，诸法无我，我身无常，苦空非我。 虽身有疾，在生死中，化度一切，而不厌倦，是名方便。 汝等又复念於我身，身不离病，病不离身，是病是身，非新非故，是惠方便。 设身有疾而寂寞故，是智方便。

"Why is this so? The four great elements combine to form what is provisionally called a 'body'; the four great elements have no master, and the body likewise has no attachment. The illness I now have arises entirely from attachment to the body—thus one should not generate attachment to the body. King Good-Seed, having understood the root of illness, should eliminate the notion of 'I' and the notion of afflictions, and extinguish the notion of dharmas.

You great kings should contemplate thus: this body is merely composed of various dharmas; this body of mine arises only from dharmas and perishes only through dharmas. This dharma-body does not know one another—when arising, it does not say, 'I arise, you perish'; when perishing, it does not say, 'I perish, you arise.' My thoughts of beings are likewise thus.

King Good-Seed, you should know and contemplate thus: this dharma-body is also inverted. This body of mine is the great affliction. You should be weary of and turn away from this body. How then can one be free from 'what is mine'? To be free from 'what is mine' is to be free from the two dharmas; to be free from the two dharmas is to be without thoughts of inner or outer, and all dharmas are equal.

How are they equal? We are eternally blissful, eternally blissful and pure; there is no self within or without, and I too am pure. These two equalities are all utterly empty. What is emptiness? It is merely names—emptiness arises from names. These two dharmas have no fixed nature in sequence. Attaining this equality, there is no other illness, only the illness of emptiness. The illness of emptiness is also empty; having understood the illness of emptiness, this is my having illness.

Now my illness is without reception yet received; I speak of the body as impermanent, yet the marks of dharmas do not perish. To establish faith and conviction, I provisionally posit a body, universally contemplating beings, arousing great compassion, and expounding the treasury of the One Vehicle. Taming this body of mine, I shall also tame all beings, removing manifold illnesses.

Now I speak of illness to sever the roots of clinging in beings. Having severed the roots of illness, there is nothing to be obtained. If there is nothing to be obtained, then clinging is severed. When all faculties are exhausted, this is my being without illness."

King Good-Seed, having heard this discourse, bowed his head in reverence, knelt, and praised: "Excellent! Excellent! Great compassionate one, for the sake of severing my attachments, you have spoken thus, taming this body of mine, and shall also tame all beings' suffering of old age, illness, and death. If not for this, we beings would live without benefit, bound by afflictions. The true one of the Sea of Emptiness has spoken to me—like one victorious in dharma, who may be called brave, and who can also remove the suffering of old age, illness, and death, abiding in the city, I have heard your discourse.

The true one of the Sea of Emptiness is likewise thus: for my having illness, you speak of having illness. My body's illness is neither real nor existent. The Treasury of Sea of Emptiness Wisdom is likewise neither real nor existent. If there are beings who contemplate this illness and do not generate attachment or views, such a person is the Treasury of the Sea of Emptiness, long since freed from the ailing body of birth and death.

Why is this so? The Treasury of Sea of Emptiness Wisdom has long since severed the afflictions subtle as dust, yet arouses great compassion. For those who love and grieve, it is weariness of mind in birth and death that causes one to lie ill. If there are beings who can generate weariness and turning away, following whatever they love, such persons, wherever they are born, are not covered by attachment or views.

Having understood the marks of dharmas, wherever they are born, they are not struck; moreover, with wisdom, they expound the dharma to beings, untying bonds—just as the Sea of Emptiness expounds the One Vehicle. All bonds are untied; having freed the body from bonds, they can free others from bonds. The bonds of self and others are all purified.

If there are beings who greedily cling to the flavors of goodness, the Sea of Emptiness strikes the notion of being bound. Afflictions have no master, and the body likewise has no self. Contemplating thus is the arising of skillful means—this is the Sea of Emptiness' liberation."

King Good-Seed, having spoken thus, gazed up at the honored countenance, bowed, and withdrew. Thereupon, the Sea of Emptiness, hearing Good-Seed's words, rejoiced greatly and addressed King Good-Seed: "Excellent! Excellent! Good man, you noble ones are my true children, with profound wisdom and unobstructed eloquence, able to understand the marks of dharmas. You are my great teacher—your wisdom is unfathomable, surpassing even my discourse.

I now reflect: King Good-Seed, your name is not in vain. You are truly able to establish the seeds that remain in the three realms—thus you are called Good-Seed. Good man, you should listen carefully as I distinguish and expound for you.

Good man, what is the bond of skillful means? It is the mind attached to views, the lesser vehicle and lesser views, adorning the Three Jewels. The seven-jeweled palace adorns the body, and one tames oneself, transforming beings, practicing dharmas of existence together, adorning the dharma within emptiness and formlessness with manifold embellishments. Such a person is bound by skillful means.

What is liberation through skillful means? Without attachment or views, one does not cling to the body as beloved, adorning it with subtlety and wonder, perfecting beings together, having understood the One Vehicle Treasury of Sea of Emptiness Wisdom, abiding unmoved, realizing emptiness as non-emptiness, speaking of existence as non-existence. With the power of skillful means, within emptiness and formlessness, one transforms the dharma, also guiding beings to tame themselves, weary of the body, not receiving any attachments. Such a person is liberated through skillful means.

Good-Seed King, if there is one lying ill, you should contemplate thus: all dharmas are without self; my body is impermanent, suffering, empty, and not-self. Though the body is ill, within birth and death, one transforms and liberates all without weariness—this is skillful means.

You should also contemplate this body of mine: the body does not leave illness, and illness does not leave the body. This illness and this body are neither new nor old—this is the skillful means of wisdom. If the body is ill yet tranquil, this is the skillful means of wisdom."

chunks.original_text: 善种大王，若有众生，有疾而外，而作是念，不调伏心，不厌离身，而贪求爱。 如是人者，是愚人法。 当知是人不离生死、地狱苦中。 若有一人，有疾而 卧，念想诸法，苦空无我，是我身疾，在生死中，而不生死，无生死故，生死无我，我於生死，亦无污行，住於常乐，亦不常乐，不寂静故，是海空行。 如是之人，永离生死、烦恼城中，虽有我身，不依身心； 虽在三界，不怀法性； 虽行於空，亦无空想。 又告善种长者大王：我身虽病，为诸众生，有疾而卧。 虽行无相，为彼众生，而度一切； 虽行无作，为彼众生，而现受身； 虽行无动，为彼众生，而作动相。 种种演说，虽行一乘海空智藏，为彼众生，而徧现身、微尘之身； 虽行智慧，转大法轮，为彼众生无明暗室，现大宝光，照彼烦恼，俱发善心，行一乘行。 说是语已，善种大王及诸群臣八千余人皆发善心，欢喜作礼，奉辞而退，各还本位，复听次言。 尔时，众中有一童子，名曰妙思，即从座起，手执莲花，正对天尊，安庠雅步，前进作礼，白天尊言：大哀天尊，云何海空住於空城七宝床中，以疾而卧？ 如是城中，悉空无有。 是我等辈及诸天王、天下人民共来闻听一乘海空秘密宝藏。 如是人者，常坐何座？ 是时天尊答妙思言：善哉善哉，善男子，大德仁者於意云何而作是问？ 汝等众中为法而来，为座而来。 善男子，我於往昔大浮黎国坐宝珠中，大如黍米，为诸众生演说法要。 当尔之时，四众同来，若人非人，俱入宝珠，亦无鞅数，宝中床座，亦无逼窄。 汝今云何城空无座？ 尔时，妙思闻是说已，长跪答言：大哀天尊，我今来者，闻此城中说一乘藏，不谓海空以疾而卧，城空无座。 於是天尊答妙思言：善男子，夫为求法，不惜身命，不缘有想，不见有相，不有色欲。 今汝师者，无疾而卧，无床而坐，非无而有，城空无宝，唯有海空，不求而求，心求法也。 不见身求，不见色求，不见说求； 不见有求，不见无求，不见有无求，不见非有无求，不见非非有无求，不见非不有无求。 夫求法者，无见苦求，无见乐求，无断集求，无修道求。 所以者何？ 法无戏论，言之为有。 以是之故，大师求法，随种种求，随种种有。 若有人言，海空真士因疾而 卧，如是人者，是名戏论，非求法也。 妙思童子，善男子，汝等当知法名海空，海空非法。 若有众生身行海空，如是人者，是求海空，非求法也。 善男子，法名一乘，一乘非法。 若有众生身行一乘，如是人者，是求一乘，非求法也。 善男子，法无处着，处着非法。 若有众生身行处着，如是人者，是求处着，非求法也。 善男子，法名无相，无相非法。 若有众生，随相而识，当和求相，非求法也。 善男子，法无可住，可住非法。 若有众生住於法中，当知是人，身行住法，非求法也。 是时四众闻是说已，七十天王、八千亿众，若人非人，得法利益，於诸法中了了明 净，苦空无我，诸行无常，生灭无我，我於法中，悉皆清净。 尔时，海空闻如是说，举体而坐，放微妙光，一一毛发各各放光，种种希有上妙功德。 师子宝座，光照东方三十六国，国中化作大王及长者子。 又照南方、西方、北方，光所及处，悉皆得见海空之身，身长丈六，坐师子座，庄严第一，微妙希有。
chunks.translated_text:
Good-Seed King, if there are beings who, though ill, entertain thoughts of unrestrained minds, not wearying of the body, and craving love and attachment—such persons follow the way of fools. Know that these beings do not depart from the suffering of birth-and-death and the torments of hell.

If there is one lying ill, contemplating all dharmas as suffering, empty, and without self—this illness of mine is within birth-and-death, yet not of birth-and-death. Since there is no birth-and-death, birth-and-death is without self. I, within birth-and-death, bear no defiled conduct, abiding in constant bliss, yet not in constant bliss, for it is not tranquil—this is the practice of oceanic emptiness.

Such a person forever departs from the city of birth-and-death and afflictions. Though possessing this body, they do not rely on body or mind; though within the three realms, they do not grasp at dharma-nature; though practicing emptiness, they hold no notion of emptiness.

Then the Great Compassionate Heavenly Honored One addressed Good-Seed Elder-King: Though my body is ill, lying for the sake of all beings who suffer; though practicing formlessness, for those beings I ferry all across; though practicing non-action, for those beings I manifest a received body; though practicing non-movement, for those beings I display movement.

Through various expositions, though practicing the single vehicle of the oceanic emptiness treasury of wisdom, for those beings I manifest bodies throughout—even bodies as minute as motes of dust. Though practicing wisdom and turning the great Dharma-wheel, for beings in the dark chamber of ignorance, I reveal the great jewel-light, illuminating their afflictions, all arousing wholesome minds and practicing the single-vehicle practice.

Having spoken thus, Good-Seed King and his eight thousand ministers all aroused wholesome minds, joyfully paid homage, took their leave, and returned to their seats, awaiting further discourse.

At that time, among the assembly was a youth named Marvelous Thought. Rising from his seat, he held a lotus flower, faced the Heavenly Honored One with dignified steps, approached, and bowed, saying: "Great Compassionate Heavenly Honored One, how does Oceanic Emptiness abide in the empty city, lying ill upon a seven-jeweled bed? In such a city, all is empty and nothing exists. We, along with the heavenly kings and the people of the world, have come together to hear the single-vehicle treasury of oceanic emptiness. Where does such a one constantly sit?"

Then the Heavenly Honored One replied to Marvelous Thought: "Excellent, excellent, good son! Noble and virtuous one, what is your intention in asking this? Have you come among this assembly for the Dharma or for a seat? Good son, in the past, in the great Floating-Ri Kingdom, I sat within a jewel no larger than a millet grain, expounding the essential Dharma for all beings. At that time, the fourfold assembly—both human and non-human—all entered the jewel, without obstruction or number. The beds and seats within the jewel were neither cramped nor narrow. How then do you say the city is empty and without a seat?"

Then Marvelous Thought, having heard this teaching, knelt and replied: "Great Compassionate Heavenly Honored One, I came here to hear of the single-vehicle treasury spoken of in this city. I did not expect Oceanic Emptiness to lie ill in an empty city without a seat."

Thereupon, the Heavenly Honored One replied to Marvelous Thought: "Good son, those who seek the Dharma spare neither body nor life, do not cling to notions of existence, do not perceive any form, and are free from sensual desire. Now, your teacher lies without illness, sits without a bed—neither non-existent nor existent. The city is empty and without treasure; only Oceanic Emptiness remains. Not seeking, yet seeking—the mind seeks the Dharma. Not seeing the body as seeking, not seeing form as seeking, not seeing speech as seeking; not seeing seeking as existent, not seeing seeking as non-existent, not seeing seeking as both existent and non-existent, not seeing seeking as neither existent nor non-existent, not seeing seeking as neither neither-existent-nor-non-existent, not seeing seeking as neither not-neither-existent-nor-non-existent.

Those who seek the Dharma do not see suffering as seeking, do not see bliss as seeking, do not see the cessation of accumulation as seeking, do not see the cultivation of the path as seeking. Why is this? The Dharma is free from idle discourse; to speak of it is to posit existence. Therefore, the great teacher seeks the Dharma in accordance with various seekings, in accordance with various existences. If one says that the true man Oceanic Emptiness lies ill, such a person engages in idle discourse and does not seek the Dharma.

Marvelous Thought, good son, you should know that the Dharma is called oceanic emptiness, yet oceanic emptiness is not the Dharma. If beings practice oceanic emptiness with their bodies, such persons seek oceanic emptiness, not the Dharma. Good son, the Dharma is called the single vehicle, yet the single vehicle is not the Dharma. If beings practice the single vehicle with their bodies, such persons seek the single vehicle, not the Dharma. Good son, the Dharma is without attachment, yet attachment is not the Dharma. If beings practice attachment with their bodies, such persons seek attachment, not the Dharma. Good son, the Dharma is called formless, yet formlessness is not the Dharma. If beings recognize by following forms and seek forms accordingly, they do not seek the Dharma. Good son, the Dharma is without abode, yet abode is not the Dharma. If beings abide within the Dharma, know that such persons practice abiding in the Dharma, not the Dharma itself."

At that time, the fourfold assembly, seventy heavenly kings, and eight thousand koṭis of beings—both human and non-human—received the benefit of the Dharma. In all dharmas, they became clear and pure, understanding suffering, emptiness, non-self, the impermanence of all conditioned things, and the absence of self in arising and ceasing. In the Dharma, all was purified for them.

Then Oceanic Emptiness, having heard these words, sat up in full, emitting subtle and wondrous light. Each hair on his body radiated light, each with various rare and supreme virtues. From his lion throne, light shone upon the thirty-six kingdoms of the eastern direction, where it transformed into great kings and sons of elders. It also illuminated the southern, western, and northern directions. Wherever the light reached, all beheld the body of Oceanic Emptiness—sixteen feet in height, seated upon a lion throne, adorned with supreme and wondrous majesty.

You should also contemplate this body of mine: the body does not leave illness, and illness does not leave the body. This illness and this body are neither new nor old—this is the skillful means of wisdom. If the body is ill yet tranquil, this is the skillful means of wisdom."

chunks.original_text: 於诸国人昔所未见，而今得见； 昔所未闻，而今得闻； 昔所未了，而今得了。 此城宝床广博包容三万二千师子之座，三十六国，亦无妨碍，於诸来众亦无逼连，安徐而坐。 妙思童子白天尊言：云何城中庄饰希有，是海空耶，非海空耶？ 城中诸物，种种奇特，师子宝座，亦无鞅数，大王小王，悉皆端严，同坐师子之座。 众中疑惑，未曾有也。 此城室中乃容无量师子宝座，亦无妨碍，於意云何？ 愿为分别解说法言。 於是天尊答妙思言：响哉善哉，善男子，此城空者，非无而有。 以是因缘，有海空真士，是名解脱，不可思议。 是诸王者，大王小王，亦是解脱，不可思议。 善男子，譬如天人入宝珠中，无所增减，如是天民安常如故，不觉不知，已入所入，唯应度者见之分明，得见天人入宝珠中，不可思议。 师子宝座入海空城，亦复如是。 善男子，譬如海水入一微尘，是海水中蛟龙、鱼龞安常如故，亦无迫迮，水性之属亦如海水，本相如故。 海空之身化作诸王，大王小王，亦复如是。 又告妙思：一切众生供养海空一乘藏者，於一微尘，皆令得见三世天尊。 又复於诸十方国土所有日月星宿，於一微妙，普皆得见。 若有大风伤动草木，一切摧折，即念海空方便之力，吸着口中，而身无损，安稳如故。 若有猛火焚烧劫尽，存念海空，火内腹中，安常如故，亦复不热，火常如故，亦不为害。 又告妙思：我住海空城中，种种方便，不可思议。 或以神力，现作海空微妙之身； 或作真身，或作老容，或作王身，或作法王身，或作贫病身，或作金身，或作凡身，或作兽身，种种化身。 种种说法，演说无常、苦、空、无我。 一切众生於其说中普令得解，俱发善心，舍身智财，求无上果。 或此骸骨而为灰尘，於一尘中复作大德，见海空城中说法，彼说我听，具足一乘甚深智慧，思惟我身从何方来，云何不绝生死恶根，得入玄门。 解脱之方，不可思议。 或复有众生闻我海空不可思议方便一乘法门，皆应号泣。 声动十方无极世界一切国土，大王小王，臣民长者，若男若女，随类而解，俱发信心，受此大法，日夜读诵，永无休息。 如是等人，同得平等海空智门。 於是说时，众中无量。 有一大王，名曰方城，即从座起，擎拳号泣，发心大愿：愿舍我身，施诸乞士，随意而取。 或取我身，手足头目，耳鼻髓脑，身肉皮骨，悉皆布施。 或施屋宅，宫殿床帐，妻子奴婢，象马车乘，金银瑠璃，砗磲玛瑙，珊瑚琥珀，真珠等宝； 衣服饮食，亦悉施散。 愿我身者，舍身受身，得住海空智慧之门、解脱法地，同听一乘微妙经典。 说此语已，彼说我听，永无疲厌。 尔时，天尊得闻方城王说是语已，心大欢喜，告方城王：善哉善哉，善男子，汝能慈故，发大誓愿，为说众生，作法桥梁，作法梯磴。 方城大王，今汝身者，是海空船，度诸众生，离烦恼城。 今汝眼者，是海空灯，为诸众生，照烦恼方。 今汝手者，是海空力，为诸众生，断烦恼城。 今汝足者，是海空车，为诸众生，运度三界。 今汝意者，是海空藏，为诸众生，种种演说、智藏经典。 今汝耳者，是海空音，为诸众生，彼说我听。 今汝鼻者，是海空风，为诸众生，扇动法教，普令众生得了海空一乘法门。
chunks.translated_text:
What the people of these lands had never seen before, they now beheld; what they had never heard, they now heard; what they had never understood, they now understood. This city’s jeweled dais, vast and all-embracing, held thirty-two thousand lion thrones, yet the thirty-six kingdoms remained unobstructed, and all who came found ample space to sit at ease. The youth Miao Si then addressed the Heavenly Venerable: “How is it that the adornments within this city are so rare and wondrous? Is this Oceanic Emptiness, or is it not? The city’s treasures are all extraordinary, its lion thrones beyond count, its great and lesser kings all dignified and majestic, seated together upon lion thrones. The assembly is filled with doubt—never has such a thing been seen. This city’s halls contain boundless lion thrones, yet nothing is hindered. What is your explanation? We wish to hear your discourse and resolve our questions.”

Thereupon, the Heavenly Venerable replied to Miao Si: “Excellent, excellent, good man! This city is emptiness—it is not nothingness, yet it is not something. For this reason, there is the true being Oceanic Emptiness, who is called liberation, beyond all thought. These kings, great and small, are also liberation, beyond all thought. Good man, it is like the devas entering a jewel: nothing is added or diminished. The celestial beings remain at ease as before, unaware that they have entered, yet those who are to be delivered see it clearly—they behold the devas entering the jewel, beyond all thought. The lion thrones entering the city of Oceanic Emptiness are likewise.

Good man, it is like the ocean entering a single mote of dust: the dragons, fish, and sea creatures within remain at ease as before, unconstrained, their watery nature unchanged, as it was originally. Oceanic Emptiness’s body, transforming into these kings—great and small—is also thus.

He further told Miao Si: “All beings who make offerings to Oceanic Emptiness of the One Vehicle Treasury cause the Threefold Heavenly Venerables of the past, present, and future to appear within a single mote of dust. Moreover, within a single subtle mote, they behold all the suns, moons, and stars of the ten directions. If a great wind arises, uprooting grasses and trees, all is shattered and broken—yet by recalling Oceanic Emptiness’s skillful power, one draws it into the mouth, and the body remains unharmed, at peace as before. If a fierce fire burns the kalpa to its end, by contemplating Oceanic Emptiness, the fire enters the belly, yet one remains at ease as before, untouched by heat, the fire unchanged, causing no harm.

He further told Miao Si: “I dwell within the city of Oceanic Emptiness, manifesting boundless skillful means beyond thought. At times, by divine power, I appear as Oceanic Emptiness’s subtle and wondrous body; at times as my true form, at times as an aged figure, at times as a king’s body, at times as a Dharma King’s body, at times as a body of poverty and sickness, at times as a golden body, at times as an ordinary body, at times as an animal’s body—innumerable transformations. I expound the Dharma in countless ways, teaching impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self. All beings who hear these teachings come to understanding, together arousing the mind of goodness, relinquishing body, wisdom, and wealth to seek the supreme fruit. Though these bones may turn to dust, within a single mote of dust, great virtue arises again, beholding Oceanic Emptiness preaching within the city. They hear my discourse, and I listen to theirs, perfecting the profound wisdom of the One Vehicle. They reflect: ‘From whence did this body come? How can the evil roots of birth and death be severed, so as to enter the mysterious gate?’ The path of liberation is beyond all thought.

Some beings, upon hearing this inconceivable One Vehicle Dharma gate of Oceanic Emptiness’s skillful means, weep aloud. Their cries shake the ten directions and the boundless worlds of all lands, moving great and lesser kings, ministers, elders, men and women—each according to their kind—to arouse faith and receive this great Dharma, reciting it day and night without cease. Such people together attain the equal wisdom gate of Oceanic Emptiness.”

As he spoke these words, among the boundless assembly, a great king named Square City rose from his seat, raised his fists, and wept, making this great vow: “I wish to relinquish this body, offering it to all who beg. Let them take as they will—my hands, feet, head, eyes, ears, nose, marrow, brain, flesh, skin, bones—I give it all in offering. I offer my dwellings, palaces, beds, curtains, wives, children, servants, elephants, horses, chariots, gold, silver, lapis lazuli, mother-of-pearl, agate, coral, amber, pearls, and other treasures; clothing, food, and drink—I scatter them all. May this body, by relinquishing and receiving form, come to dwell in the wisdom gate of Oceanic Emptiness, the ground of liberation, to hear together the subtle sutra of the One Vehicle.”

Having spoken these words, they heard his discourse, and I listened, never growing weary.

Then the Heavenly Venerable, having heard King Square City’s words, rejoiced greatly and said to him: “Excellent, excellent, good man! Because of your compassion, you have aroused this great vow, becoming a bridge and ladder of the Dharma for all beings. King Square City, now your body is the ship of Oceanic Emptiness, ferrying all beings from the city of afflictions. Now your eyes are the lamp of Oceanic Emptiness, illuminating the paths of affliction for all beings. Now your hands are the strength of Oceanic Emptiness, severing the city of afflictions for all beings. Now your feet are the chariot of Oceanic Emptiness, transporting all beings across the three realms. Now your mind is the treasury of Oceanic Emptiness, expounding the sutras of wisdom and the treasury of teachings for all beings. Now your ears are the voice of Oceanic Emptiness, so that they hear my discourse, and I listen to theirs. Now your nose is the wind of Oceanic Emptiness, fanning the Dharma teachings so that all beings come to understand the One Vehicle Dharma gate of Oceanic Emptiness.”

chunks.original_text: 於是天尊又告方城大王：长者，汝今得入一乘法门，不可思议地，观察众生住烦恼城，如电石光，忽有忽无。 以是因缘，汝能布施身手头目、象马车乘、金银等宝，悉皆施散，难施能施，难舍能舍。 汝能桥梁，一切众生离生死城。 汝之功德，不可思议。 又告方城大王：长者，善男子，汝行慈悲，为众生故； 汝行舍身，无烦恼故； 汝行布施，无贫穷故； 汝行清净，无贪瞋故； 汝行听法，无愚痴故； 汝舍王位，无贵贱故； 汝舍妻子，无亲爱故； 汝行大慈，显一乘故； 汝行精进，度众生故； 汝行智慧，了众生故； 汝行方便，示现法故； 汝行功德，拔众生故； 汝行持戒，灭三毒故； 汝行海空，畏生死故； 汝行正念，除恶因故； 汝行建造，生福德故。

Then the Heavenly Venerable further addressed King Great Citadel: "Elder, you have now entered the One Vehicle Dharma gate, abiding in the inconceivable realm, observing beings dwelling in the city of afflictions—like the flash of flint and stone, suddenly appearing, suddenly vanishing. For this reason, you are able to offer your body, hands, eyes, head, elephants, horses, chariots, gold, silver, and all treasures, scattering them all without reserve—what is hard to give, you give; what is hard to relinquish, you relinquish. You become the bridge for all beings to depart the city of birth and death. Your merit and virtue are inconceivable."

The Heavenly Venerable again addressed King Great Citadel: "Elder, good son, you practice compassion for the sake of all beings; you practice relinquishing the body because you are free from afflictions; you practice generosity because you are free from poverty; you practice purity because you are free from greed and anger; you practice listening to the Dharma because you are free from ignorance; you relinquish the royal throne because you are free from notions of noble and base; you relinquish wife and children because you are free from attachment and love; you practice great compassion to reveal the One Vehicle; you practice diligence to ferry all beings; you practice wisdom to understand all beings; you practice skillful means to manifest the Dharma; you practice merit and virtue to liberate all beings; you practice upholding precepts to extinguish the three poisons; you practice Oceanic Emptiness because you fear birth and death; you practice right mindfulness to eradicate evil causes; you practice construction to generate blessings and virtue."

chunks.original_text: 说是语已，城中四座忽有诸天仙童、玉女三十三人闻大哀天尊为王说法，即便现身，从空中来，手执莲花，以散座所，纷纭杂杳，如大雪雨，满於座所。 复有妙音香花、筝筑箜篌，铿锵和雅，隐隐轸轸，徧於座所。 复有凤皇、孔雀、鹦鹉，飞翔行列，徧於座所。 方城大王及诸群臣心大惶怖，白天尊言：大哀天尊，云何天人仙童玉女散此妙花？ 如此花香，为从天来，为自然来，为树而生，为空而有？ 尔时，天尊闻是语已，即便答言：不也，大王。 如此花者，皆是清净不可思议华。 所以者何？ 言清净者，不内不外，不从天生，不自然生，亦不树生，亦不空生，亦不有生，不空有生。 离空有故，说此花生。 何以故？ 一切说法皆是清 净，是清净者，即是妙花。 以是因缘，不从天生，不自然生，不空有生，亦不树生。 何以故？ 若有生生，则有证信； 有证信者，则诽谤生。 知是说者，毁灭一乘大慈经典。 又告方城大王：长者，今此城中常有此花，复有他方天人玉女来会不绝。 常有凤凰、孔雀、鹦鹉、筝筑、箜篌、希有之事。 汝等勿疑。 清净之花，不可思议华，希有之花，难思难说。 方城大王闻是说已，心大欢喜，即便问言：云何哀尊说言天花即是清净无烦恼生？ 若如是者，一切众生以此天花供养哀尊，即得通达无烦恼生。 若得通达，唯花而得。 云何说言修行海空而得通达？ 於是天尊答大王曰：善男子，言通达者，若有一人以此天花供养海空，所以而言得通达者，即是海空，海空通达，即是此花。 若有人行海空通达，即无烦恼，至於地狱，亦无烦恼； 示行地狱，亦无地狱，无受罪身； 示饿鬼形，亦无饿鬼，无饥渴想，具足功德，无饿鬼身； 示行贪欲，无贪欲想，常住光明，照烦恼身：示行瞋恚，无瞋恚想，清 净思微，无瞋恚本； 示行悭贪，无悭贪想，弘喜大慈，舍身布施，无悭贪想； 示行懈怠，无懈怠想； 示入魔界，而无魔想； 示行说法，无说法想； 示住宝城，无宝城想； 示身有疾，而无疾想。 如是行者，是海空达。 汝等应当供养此花，即是供养一乘海空常乐之道，示行方便，入海空城，安住不动。 说是语已，方城大王俱起作礼，长跪稽首，白天尊言：云何海空真士大德是我大师，为我等辈说大妙法，种种譬喻，不可思议？ 海空身者，父母妻子、宗亲眷属、朋友知识、弟兄姊妹，悉谁是者？ 奴婢僮仆、象马车乘、城邑舍宅，在何方所？ 国主人民、后妃太子，是谁为宗？ 唯愿哀尊为我等辈分别解说。 尔时，天尊闻是说已，含笑隐几，答大王曰：善哉善哉，善男子，汝等大王善能问决海空身者，我当为汝分别解说，令众得明海空经典。 於是天尊而偈答曰： 汝等方城王，一心谛听受，我当为汝故。

Having spoken these words, suddenly from the four directions of the city, thirty-three celestial youths and jade maidens, hearing the Great Compassionate Heavenly Venerable expound the Dharma to the king, instantly manifested their forms. Descending from the sky, they scattered lotus blossoms over the assembly, swirling and drifting like a great snowfall, filling the entire seating area. Then came wondrous sounds of fragrant flowers, zithers, harps, and lutes—resonant and harmonious, softly echoing throughout the gathering. Phoenixes, peacocks, and parrots soared in orderly flight, circling the assembly.

King Fangcheng and his ministers, seized with great awe, addressed the Heavenly Venerable: “Great Compassionate Heavenly Venerable, why do these celestial beings, youths, and jade maidens scatter such wondrous flowers? Is this fragrant blossom from heaven, or does it arise naturally? Does it grow from trees, or does it exist in empty space?”

Then the Heavenly Venerable, having heard these words, replied: “Not so, great king. These flowers are all pure and inconceivable blossoms. Why? When I speak of purity, it is neither internal nor external, neither born of heaven nor arising naturally, neither growing from trees nor existing in empty space, neither born of being nor born of emptiness. Because it transcends both emptiness and being, this flower is said to arise. Why? All teachings are pure; this purity is the wondrous flower. For this reason, it is neither born of heaven nor arising naturally, neither born of emptiness nor being, nor growing from trees. Why? If there were a birth of birth, there would be verification and faith; with verification and faith, slander would arise. To know this teaching is to destroy the *One Vehicle Great Compassion Sutra*.”

The Heavenly Venerable further addressed King Fangcheng: “Noble one, within this city, such flowers are ever-present, and celestial beings and jade maidens from other realms gather here without cease. Phoenixes, peacocks, parrots, zithers, harps, and rare wonders are always here. Do not doubt. These pure and inconceivable flowers, these rare blossoms, are difficult to conceive and express.”

Hearing this, King Fangcheng rejoiced greatly and asked: “How does the Compassionate Venerable say that celestial flowers are born of purity and freedom from afflictions? If this is so, then all beings who offer these celestial flowers to the Compassionate Venerable would attain realization of birth free from afflictions. If realization is attained solely through flowers, why speak of cultivating Oceanic Emptiness to attain realization?”

The Heavenly Venerable replied to the king: “Good son, when I speak of realization, if one offers these celestial flowers to Oceanic Emptiness, then to say one attains realization is to speak of Oceanic Emptiness itself. Oceanic Emptiness is realization, which is this flower. If one cultivates Oceanic Emptiness and attains realization, one is free from afflictions. Even in hell, there are no afflictions; though manifesting in hell, there is no hell, no body to suffer punishment. Though manifesting as a hungry ghost, there is no hungry ghost, no hunger or thirst, only the perfection of merit and virtue, no body of a hungry ghost. Though manifesting in desire, there is no thought of desire, abiding constantly in radiant light, illuminating the body of afflictions. Though manifesting in anger, there is no thought of anger, only pure and subtle contemplation, no root of anger. Though manifesting in stinginess, there is no thought of stinginess, only vast joy and great compassion, relinquishing the body in generosity, no thought of stinginess. Though manifesting in laziness, there is no thought of laziness. Though entering the demon realm, there is no thought of demons. Though manifesting in teaching the Dharma, there is no thought of teaching. Though dwelling in a jeweled city, there is no thought of a jeweled city. Though manifesting illness, there is no thought of illness. Such a practitioner is one who has realized Oceanic Emptiness. You should make offerings to this flower, for it is the offering to the One Vehicle Oceanic Emptiness, the path of constant bliss. Through skillful means, one enters the city of Oceanic Emptiness and abides immovably.”

Having spoken these words, King Fangcheng and his assembly rose, bowed, knelt, and prostrated, addressing the Heavenly Venerable: “How is it that the Oceanic Emptiness true person of great virtue is our great teacher, expounding for us the wondrous Dharma with various parables, beyond conception? Who are the parents, wife, children, relatives, friends, companions, brothers, and sisters of the Oceanic Emptiness being? Who are the servants, attendants, elephants, horses, chariots, cities, villages, and dwellings? Where are they? Who are the sovereign, the people, the queen, and the crown prince? To whom do they belong? We beseech the Compassionate Venerable to explain and clarify for us.”

Then the Heavenly Venerable, having heard these words, smiled faintly, leaned on his armrest, and replied to the king: “Excellent, excellent, good son! Great king, you have skillfully inquired about the being of Oceanic Emptiness. I shall explain and clarify for you, so that all may understand the *Oceanic Emptiness Sutra*.”

Then the Heavenly Venerable responded in verse:
“You, King Fangcheng,
Listen single-mindedly,
For I shall expound for you.”
